docs.lead_paragraph: They may be rated as suitable for young teenagers, but many of the video games sold for use at home are hardly kid stuff. Researchers from Harvard analyzed 81 ''T-rated'' games and found violence in almost all of them: the number of ''deaths'' per hour averaged 122.
docs.abstract: Harvard researchers, led by Kevin Haninger and Dr Kimberly M Thompson of Children's Hospital Boston, finds that T-rated video games, which Entertainment Software Rating Board suggests are for children 13 and older, average 122 deaths per hour; find that 98 percent of games contain intentional acts of violence; suggest that parents would be surprised by content; report appears in Medscape General Medicine and Journal of American Medical Assn; drawing (S)
